TITLE: MS 4 Progress Note
   Chief Complaint: PNA, critical AS
   24 Hour Events:
   - RT continued to suction moderate amounts of bloody secretions from ET
   tube and Hct decreased from 33.4 to 28.6.  Patient was transfused 1 u
   FFP and 1 u pRBC.
   - Patient
s PEEP decreased from 10 to 5 and later tried on pressure
   support, which she briefly tolerated before becoming more uncomfortable
   and she was placed back on CMV
   - She became transiently hypotensive with systolic BPs in the 100
   when she received propofol bolus and bag-mask ventilation; now resolved
   with SBP in 120
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Vancomycin - [**2182-5-10**] 01:15 AM
   Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) - [**2182-5-10**] 05:57 AM

   Propofol - 15 mcg/Kg/min

   Famotidine (Pepcid) - [**2182-5-10**] 02:30 AM
   Lorazepam (Ativan) - [**2182-5-10**] 04:01 AM

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:20.5/37.9/1.9, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:26/6/0.62, ALT / AST:51/41, Alk Phos / T Bili:176/1.8,
   Amylase / Lipase:/28, Differential-Neuts:96.9 %, Lymph:1.5 %, Mono:1.3
   %, Eos:0.1 %, Fibrinogen:298 mg/dL, Lactic Acid:2.0 mmol/L, Albumin:2.7
   g/dL, LDH:404 IU/L, Ca++:7.7 mg/dL, Mg++:2.3 mg/dL, PO4:4.8 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   75F with h/o aortic stenosis, COPD, admitted to OSH with pneumonia,
   complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, ARF,
   transferred for difficulty weaning and question of valvuloplasty.
   .
   #)Respiratory failure- Likely multifactorial, with contributions from
   apparent RLL PNA, pulmonary edema 2/2 systolic CHF requiring
   intermittent diuresis, RLL pleural effusion s/p 800cc thoracentesis
   (culture data not available), and an episode of pulmonary hemorhhage
   felt [**12-31**] anticoagulation.  Overnight she did not tolerate PS trial due
   to discomfort, but oxygenation has been adequate.  Bloody secretions
   suctioned overnight suggest that pulmonary bleed may be intermittently
   continuing.  Sputum culture growing yeast only.
   - hold off on further diuresis given concern for critical AS.
   - repeat bronch this am
   - review CT imaging tonight, consider CT CHEST following bronch
   - obtain TTE, consider TEE to evaluate mitral valve
   - continue vancomcyin/zosyn for HCAP.
   - f/u OSH blood, sputum, and thoracentesis cultures (call in AM, per
   LDH, fluid was transudative, but protein unknown, empyema unlikelygiven
   pH 7.5).
   - wean peep, repeat ABG tonight, consider trial PS.
   - continue prednisone, start tapering as below.
   .
   # aortic stenosis - report of critical AS on TTE at OSH.  unclear what
   her baseline functional status is, she does not have regular angina, or
   syncope
   - repeat TTE
   - consider cardiology consult in AM.
   - hold off on further diuresis, nitrates.
   .
   # ARF - no known renal dysfunction.  found to have mild left
   hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by urology with plan to follow
   clinically.  ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**] diuresis vs aortic
   stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine lytes suggest
   pre-renal etiology.
   - check UA/UCx.
   - check urine lytes.
   - renal ultrasound
   - follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for
   UOP<30cc/hr.
   .
   # bacteremia - source unclear, but likely pulmonary given recent
   pneumonia.
   - continue vancomycin.
   - TTE in AM, and consider TEE.
   .
   # transaminitis - h/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  abdominal usn and ct abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   Lipase not elevated
   - trend LFTs
   - repeat abdominal usn in AM.
   .
   # thrombocytopenia - more likely [**12-31**] underlying liver disease, now with
   reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  ddx also includes DIC,
   HUS/TTP given mild ARF, and HITT, though time course is unclear (he
   received heparin sc tid and lovenox at OSH)
   - check smear to r/o schistocytes (ARF, anemia, thrombocytopenia).
   - check DIC labs.
   - check for HIT.
   .
   # COPD - unclear baseline [**Name (NI) 4232**], but not on home O2.  no clear wheezing
   on exam presently, so feel COPD less likely.
   - taper prednisone 60mg po qdaily to 50mg x3d.
   - continue albuterol, atrovent inhalers.
   - obtain OSH [**Name (NI) 4232**] in AM.
   .
   # h/o aortic valvular thrombus - chronically anticoagulated, though
   held in the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrage (though only
   received 1U PRBC for this at OSH).   no thrombus seen on his recent TTE
   at OSH.
   - hold lovenox/coumadin for now, discuss with cardiology in AM based on
   repeat TTE here.
   - cardiology consult following echo.
   .
   # sacral decub - pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - air mattress.
   - wound care consult.
   .
   # h/o hyponatremia - resolved presently
   - trend na daily.
   .
   # OA - receiving morphine 2mg po prn pain.  per husband, she takes
   percocet at home for pain, but he is unsure where.  a rheumatology note
   indicates she takes percocet for chronic intermittent chest wall pain.
   - continue morphine 0.5mg iv q6hr prn pain.
   .
   # anxiety - per husband, takes anti-anxiety medications at home, and
   receiving lorazepam 0.5-2mg q1hr prn agitation at OSH.
   - continue prn ativan, and monitor for s/sx of withdrawl.
   .
   # elevated FSBS - no known history of DM,  but on steroids, with
   elevated FSBS.
   - cover with HISS.
   .
   # h/o SVT
 monitor on tele
   .
   # HTN - hold lisinopril given ARF, avoid nitro gtt given AS.
   .
   # hyperlipidemia
hold home statin given transaminitis.
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now.
   - nutrition consult in AM re tube feeds.
   - consider replacing NGT with OGT if not getting extubated soon.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots, PPI.
   .
   # Access: PIV, L IJ TLC, A-LINE.
   .
   # Code: FULL CODE
   .
   # Communication: Patient, son [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9284**], [**Hospital3 **]
   floor [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9285**].
   .
   # Disposition: pending above
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO, nutrition c./s
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2182-5-9**] 07:00 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2182-5-9**] 07:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:  oral care

   Communication:  Comments:

   Disposition:ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, COPD, and pneumonia, who was admitted to the ICU due to hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, ARF, and question of valvuloplasty. She has been experiencing bloody secretions, suctioned overnight, and has not tolerated pressure support trials due to discomfort. Her oxygenation has been adequate, but she has not been weaned from mechanical ventilation. She has a history of autoimmune hepatitis, and her liver function tests are elevated. She also has thrombocytopenia, which is likely related to underlying liver disease and bacteremia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she requires ongoing mechanical ventilation. She has not tolerated pressure support trials, and her oxygenation is adequate, but not optimal.
2. Pulmonary edema: The patient has a history of systolic CHF, and her pulmonary edema is likely related to this condition.
3. Pulmonary hemorrhage: The patient has experienced bloody secretions, which suggests that she may be continuing to bleed intermittently.
4. Bacteremia: The patient has a source of bacteremia, likely pulmonary, and is being treated with vancomycin.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely related to underlying liver disease and bacteremia.
6. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver function tests, which may be related to autoimmune hepatitis or underlying liver disease.
7. ARF: The patient has acute renal failure, which may be related to pre-renal etiology, aortic stenosis, or obstruction.
8. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient has developed a stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, which requires wound care and air mattress support.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and pressure support trials as needed.
2. Repeat bronchoscopy and obtain CT imaging to evaluate pulmonary edema and hemorrhage.
3. Obtain TTE and consider TEE to evaluate mitral valve and aortic stenosis.
4. Continue vancomycin and consider cardiology consult.
5. Trend LFTs and repeat abdominal ultrasound to evaluate liver function and transaminitis.
6. Check for DIC labs and consider HIT.
7. Continue prednisone and taper as needed.
8. Monitor for signs of withdrawal from lorazepam.
9. Consider nutrition consult and replacement of NGT with OGT if not getting extubated soon.
10. Monitor for signs of infection and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed.

Note: The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is pending further evaluation and treatment.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and autoimmune hepatitis, who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with pneumonia, hypoxic respiratory failure, and acute renal failure (ARF). She has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1Â°C, heart rate of 67 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 130/65 mmHg. Her oxygen saturation is 99% on 40% FiO2.

The patient has been experiencing bloody secretions, which have been suctioned from her endotracheal tube, and her hemoglobin level has decreased from 33.4 to 28.6 g/dL. She has been transfused with one unit of fresh frozen plasma and one unit of packed red blood cells.

The patient's respiratory status is complicated by her critical aortic stenosis, which is making it difficult to wean her off the ventilator. She has also been experiencing intermittent pulmonary hemorrhage, which has been felt to be contributing to her bloody secretions.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of troponin-T, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and creatine kinase (CK), which may indicate cardiac or pulmonary damage. Her liver function tests (LFTs) are abnormal, with elevated levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST), which may indicate liver damage.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is complicated by her critical aortic stenosis, which is making it difficult to wean her off the ventilator. She has also been experiencing intermittent pulmonary hemorrhage, which has been felt to be contributing to her bloody secretions.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's ARF is likely caused by her critical aortic stenosis and may be contributing to her bloody secretions.
3. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia is likely caused by her recent pneumonia and may be contributing to her bloody secretions.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be caused by her underlying liver disease, reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia, or DIC.
5. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis may be caused by her autoimmune hepatitis or liver damage from her critical aortic stenosis.
6. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient has developed a stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, which may be caused by her immobility and pressure on her sacrum.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for developing pneumonia due to her intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for developing sepsis due to her bacteremia and ARF.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient is at risk for developing cardiac arrhythmias due to her critical aortic stenosis and electrolyte imbalances.
4. Liver damage: The patient is at risk for developing liver damage due to her autoimmune hepatitis and transaminitis.
5. Renal failure: The patient is at risk for developing renal failure due to her ARF and critical aortic stenosis.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and weaning off the ventilator as tolerated.
2. Continue antibiotics for her pneumonia and bacteremia.
3. Monitor her respiratory status closely and consider a trial of pressure support ventilation.
4. Monitor her renal function closely and consider dialysis if necessary.
5. Monitor her liver function tests closely and consider treatment for her autoimmune hepatitis.
6. Monitor her sacral decubitus ulcer closely and consider wound care consult.
7. Continue to monitor her electrolyte levels and consider treatment for her transaminitis.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, ARF, bacteremia, thrombocytopenia, transaminitis, and sacral decubitus ulcer. She requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and to improve her chances of recovery.

   Assessment and Plan
   75F with h/o aortic stenosis, COPD, admitted to OSH with pneumonia,
   complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, ARF,
   transferred for difficulty weaning and question of valvuloplasty.
   .
   # hypoxia - likely multifactorial, with contributions from apparent RLL
   PNA, pulmonary edema 2/2 systolic CHF requiring intermittent diuresis,
   RLL pleural effusion s/p 800cc thoracentesis (culture data not
   available), and an episode of pulmonary hemorhhage felt [**12-31**]
   anticoagulation.  at present, she is oxygenating well, and could be
   weaned down on her PEEP, with consideration of PS trial.  she
   continuous to have considerably bloody secretions. while her CXR is
   without significant pulmonary edema, focal infiltrate, she continues to
   have a RLL effusion.
   - hold off on further diuresis given concern for critical AS.
   - review CT imaging tonight, consider CT CHEST in AM.
   - obtain TTE in AM.
   - continue vancomcyin/zosyn for HCAP.
   - check sputum cx.
   - f/u OSH blood, sputum, and thoracentesis cultures (call in AM, per
   LDH, fluid was transudative, but protein unknown, empyema unlikelygiven
   pH 7.5).
   - wean peep, repeat ABG tonight, consider trial PS.
   - consider repeat bronch in AM if persistantly blood secretions.
   - switch sedation to fentanyl/versed bolus sedation.
   - continue prednisone, start tapering as below.
   .
   # aortic stenosis - report of critical AS on TTE at OSH.  unclear what
   her baseline functional status is, as per her husband, she does not
   have regular angina, or syncope.  she's been "sleeping all the time"
   the past few weeks, so unclear if she has been having symptoms of CHF.
   per discharge summary was transferred here for discussion of valve
   surgery/valvuloplasty.
   - repeat TTE in AM.
   - consider cardiology consult in AM.
   - hold off on further diuresis, nitrates.
   .
   # ARF - no known renal dysfunction.  found to have mild left
   hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by urology with plan to follow
   clinically.  ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**] diuresis vs aortic
   stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction.
   - check UA/UCx.
   - check urine lytes.
   - renal ultrasound in AM.
   - follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for
   UOP<30cc/hr.
   .
   # bacteremia - source unclear, but likely pulmonary given recent
   pneumonia.
   - continue vancomycin.
   - TTE in AM, and consider TEE.
   .
   # transaminitis - h/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  abdominal usn and ct abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   - trend LFTs, add-on lipase.
   - repeat abdominal usn in AM.
   .
   # thrombocytopenia - more likely [**12-31**] underlying liver disease, now with
   reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  ddx also includes DIC,
   HUS/TTP given mild ARF, and HITT, though time course is unclear (he
   received heparin sc tid and lovenox at OSH)
   - check smear to r/o schistocytes (ARF, anemia, thrombocytopenia).
   - check DIC labs.
   - hold off sending HITT assay unless drops further.
   .
   # COPD - unclear baseline [**Name (NI) 4232**], but not on home O2.  no clear wheezing
   on exam presently, so feel COPD less likely.
   - taper prednisone 60mg po qdaily to 50mg x3d.
   - continue albuterol, atrovent inhalers.
   - obtain OSH [**Name (NI) 4232**] in AM.
   .
   # h/o aortic valvular thrombus - chronically anticoagulated, though
   held in the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrage (though only
   received 1U PRBC for this at OSH).   no thrombus seen on his recent TTE
   at OSH.
   - hold lovenox/coumadin for now, discuss with cardiology in AM based on
   repeat TTE here.
   - cardiology consult in AM.
   .
   # sacral decub - pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - air mattress.
   - wound care consult.
   .
   # h/o hyponatremia - resolved presently, receiving 300cc free water
   boluses.
   - trend na in am.
   .
   # OA - receiving morphine 2mg po prn pain.  per husband, she takes
   percocet at home for pain, but he is unsure where.  a rheumatology note
   indicates she takes percocet for chronic intermittent chest wall pain.
   - continue morphine 0.5mg iv q6hr prn pain.
   .
   # anxiety - per husband, takes anti-anxiety medications at home, and
   receiving lorazepam 0.5-2mg q1hr prn agitation at OSH.
   - continue prn ativan, and monitor for s/sx of withdrawl.
   .
   # elevated FSBS - no known history of DM,  but on steroids, with
   elevated FSBS.
   - cover with HISS.
   .
   # h/o SVT - continue cardizem 60mg po q6h.
   .
   # h/o GERD - switch to famotidine given pt intubated.
   .
   # HTN - hold lisinopril given ARF, avoid nitro gtt given AS.
   .
   # hyperlipidemia - continue home regimen of statin.
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now.
   - nutrition consult in AM re tube feeds.

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of aortic stenosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and pneumonia, admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure, acute kidney injury (ARF), and suspected bacteremia. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1Â°C, heart rate of 67 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 130/65 mmHg. Her laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), indicating renal dysfunction and potential liver damage.

The patient's medical history is significant for aortic stenosis, which was recently diagnosed as critical aortic stenosis on transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). She also has a history of autoimmune hepatitis and has been taking prednisone for chronic intermittent chest wall pain.

The patient's current condition is complicated by a range of potential medical complications, including:

1. Bacteremia: The patient has a positive blood culture, and the source of the bacteremia is unclear, but likely pulmonary given recent pneumonia.
2. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient has mild left hydronephrosis and is at risk for further renal dysfunction.
3. Aortic stenosis: The patient has critical aortic stenosis, which may be contributing to her hypoxic respiratory failure and ARF.
4. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may be related to autoimmune hepatitis or a reaction to antibiotics.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a platelet count of 89, which may be related to underlying liver disease, bacteremia, or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
6. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient has a stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, which may be related to prolonged immobility and pressure.
7. Hyponatremia: The patient has a history of hyponatremia, which has resolved with fluid replacement.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue vancomycin and Zosyn for HCAP.
2. Obtain TTE and CT imaging to assess aortic stenosis and potential valvuloplasty.
3. Wean PEEP and consider trial PS.
4. Check sputum cx and follow up on OSH blood, sputum, and thoracentesis cultures.
5. Hold off on further diuresis given concern for critical AS.
6. Review CT imaging tonight and consider CT chest in the morning.
7. Obtain TEE in the morning and consider cardiology consult.
8. Follow up on UOP and consider renal ultrasound.
9. Trend LFTs and add-on lipase.
10. Repeat abdominal US and CT abdomen/pelvis in the morning.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's critical aortic stenosis may lead to further cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrest or arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's pneumonia and hypoxic respiratory failure may lead to further respiratory complications, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Renal complications: The patient's ARF may worsen, leading to further renal dysfunction and potential need for dialysis.
4. Hepatic complications: The patient's transaminitis may worsen, leading to further liver damage and potential need for liver transplantation.
5. Hematological complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to further bleeding complications.
6. Wound complications: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer may worsen, leading to further wound complications and potential need for surgical intervention.
7. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's hyponatremia may recur, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual receiving invasive ventilation, multi-lumen, and arterial line support in the ICU. The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure, acute, and impaired skin integrity.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.7Â°C, heart rate of 67 bpm, blood pressure of 130/65 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 16 inspirations per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 99% on 40% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show mild leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 22.4 K/uL, and mild anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.7 g/dL. The patient's renal function is normal, with a creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL. The patient's liver function is also normal, with an albumin level of 2.7 g/dL.

The patient's blood cultures, sputum culture, and nasal swab are pending. The patient has received vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam antibiotics.

The patient's respiratory support is optimized, with a tidal volume of 500 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 11 cmH2O, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 10 cmH2O. The patient's arterial blood gas results show a pH of 7.41, partial pressure of oxygen of 58 mmHg, and partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 33 mmHg.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's unstable condition. The patient's peripheral vascular examination is not assessed, and the patient's skin, neurologic, and abdominal examinations are not documented.

The patient's laboratory results and imaging studies are pending. The patient's code status is full code, and the patient's disposition is ICU care.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's pending blood cultures, sputum culture, and nasal swab may indicate the presence of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and mortality.
3. Skin breakdown: The patient's impaired skin integrity can worsen, leading to increased risk of infection, tissue damage, and potential amputation.
4. Catheter-related complications: The patient's multi-lumen and arterial lines can lead to complications such as infection, bleeding, and thrombosis.
5. Renal failure: The patient's mild anemia and mild leukocytosis may indicate the presence of underlying kidney disease, which can worsen during the patient's ICU stay.
6. Liver dysfunction: The patient's normal liver function tests may not accurately reflect the patient's liver function, which can worsen during the patient's ICU stay.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure and heart rate may fluctuate, leading to cardiovascular instability and potential cardiac arrest.
8. Neurologic complications: The patient's pending imaging studies may indicate the presence of neurologic complications such as stroke, seizures, or brain edema.
9. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's pending imaging studies may indicate the presence of gastrointestinal complications such as bowel obstruction, perforation, or bleeding.
10. Infection: The patient's pending blood cultures, sputum culture, and nasal swab may indicate the presence of infection, which can lead to organ dysfunction and mortality.

   Assessment and Plan
   75F with h/o aortic stenosis, COPD, admitted to OSH with pneumonia,
   complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, ARF,
   transferred for difficulty weaning and question of valvuloplasty.
   .
   #)Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   PNA, pulmonary edema 2/2 systolic CHF requiring intermittent diuresis
   and s/p drainage 800cc reportedly transudative fluid via R
   thoracentesis at OSH, and pulmonary hemorrhage felt [**12-31**] anticoagulation
   and ?trauma. Bronch yesterday showed lingular abrasion as likely
   source; continuing to suction bloody secretions. Sputum cx growing only
   yeast to date.
   - Patient appears to have been treated with full course of vanc/CTX.
   D/c zosyn and vanc once this is confirmed.
   - F/u OSH cx (blood, sputum, thoracentesis)
   - Monitor Hct q6h
   - Gentle diuresis to run her even
   - F/u final read of CT chest
   - Wean PEEP, trial of pressure support as tolerated
   - Intubate x 13 days, may need to have trach
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD
   .
   # Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of hospital stay at
   [**Hospital1 **] with hx of vegetation on aortic valve (not on current TTE).
   - Start PCN for Strep Viridans.
   - ID consult for treatment course and f/u as outpatient for
   endocarditis.
   .
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope
   - Will notify Cards on Monday of possible evaluation for valvuloplasty
   - not candidate for AV replacement given clinical status
   - hold off on nitrates.
   - gentle lasix for goal even
   .
   # ARF - no known renal dysfunction.  found to have mild left
   hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by urology with plan to follow
   clinically.  ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**] diuresis vs aortic
   stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine lytes suggest
   pre-renal etiology.
   - follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for
   UOP<30cc/hr.
   .
   # transaminitis - h/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  abdominal usn and ct abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   Lipase not elevated
   - trend LFTs
   - Send lipase and trigs.
   .
   # thrombocytopenia - more likely [**12-31**] underlying liver disease, now with
   reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  ddx also includes DIC,
   HUS/TTP given mild ARF, and HITT, though time course is unclear (he
   received heparin sc tid and lovenox at OSH)
   - check smear to r/o schistocytes (ARF, anemia, thrombocytopenia).
   - check DIC labs.
   - check for HIT.
   .
   # COPD - unclear baseline [**Name (NI) 4232**], but not on home O2.  no clear wheezing
   on exam presently, so feel COPD less likely.
   - taper prednisone 60mg po qdaily to 50mg x3d.
   - continue albuterol, atrovent inhalers.
   - obtain OSH [**Name (NI) 4232**] in AM.
   .
   # h/o aortic valvular thrombus - chronically anticoagulated, though
   held in the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrage (though only
   received 1U PRBC for this at OSH).   no thrombus seen on his recent TTE
   at OSH.
   - hold lovenox/coumadin for now, discuss with cardiology based on
   repeat TTE here.
   - cardiology consult following echo.
   .
   # sacral decub - pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - air mattress.
   - wound care consult.
   .
   # h/o hyponatremia - resolved presently
   - trend na daily.
   .
   # OA - receiving morphine 2mg po prn pain.  per husband, she takes
   percocet at home for pain, but he is unsure where.  a rheumatology note
   indicates she takes percocet for chronic intermittent chest wall pain.
   - continue morphine 0.5mg iv q6hr prn pain.
   .
   # anxiety - per husband, takes anti-anxiety medications at home, and
   receiving lorazepam 0.5-2mg q1hr prn agitation at OSH.
   - continue prn ativan, and monitor for s/sx of withdrawl.
   .
   # elevated FSBS - no known history of DM,  but on steroids, with
   elevated FSBS.
   - cover with HISS.
   .
   # h/o SVT
 monitor on tele
   .
   # HTN - hold lisinopril given ARF, avoid nitro gtt given AS.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia
hold home statin given transaminitis.

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of aortic stenosis, COPD, and pneumonia, who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and acute kidney injury (ARF). She has been treated with antibiotics, diuresis, and drainage of pleural effusion. Her current condition is complicated by:

1. Respiratory failure: Multifactorial, including pneumonia, pulmonary edema, and pulmonary hemorrhage.
2. Endocarditis: Blood cultures positive for Streptococcus viridans, and vegetation on the aortic valve.
3. Critical aortic stenosis: Unclear baseline functional status, but not a candidate for valve replacement.
4. ARF: Mild left hydronephrosis, and possible pre-renal etiology.
5. Transaminitis: Elevated liver enzymes, possibly related to autoimmune hepatitis or cirrhosis.
6. Thrombocytopenia: Likely related to underlying liver disease, bacteremia, and pneumonia.
7. Sacral decubitus ulcer: Stage 2, does not probe to bone.
8. Hyponatremia: Resolved, but trending daily.
9. Osteoarthritis: Receiving morphine for pain.
10. Anxiety: Receiving lorazepam for agitation.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia progression: Continued suctioning of bloody secretions may exacerbate the condition.
2. Endocarditis progression: Failure to treat the infection may lead to further valve damage and potential heart failure.
3. ARF progression: Continued renal dysfunction may lead to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
4. Transaminitis progression: Continued liver damage may lead to fulminant liver failure.
5. Thrombocytopenia progression: Continued bleeding may lead to further complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.
6. Sacral decubitus ulcer progression: Failure to treat the ulcer may lead to further tissue damage and potential sepsis.
7. Hyponatremia progression: Continued sodium imbalance may lead to further complications, such as seizures or coma.
8. Osteoarthritis progression: Continued pain and limited mobility may lead to further complications, such as pressure ulcers or decreased lung function.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for pneumonia and endocarditis.
2. Monitor liver enzymes and trending LFTs.
3. Monitor platelet count and trending DIC labs.
4. Continue diuresis and gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr.
5. Trend LFTs and lipase.
6. Check for schistocytes and HIT.
7. Continue air mattress and wound care consult for sacral decubitus ulcer.
8. Trend Na daily and continue morphine for pain.
9. Continue lorazepam for agitation and monitor for s/sx of withdrawal.
10. Cover with HISS for elevated FSBS.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, COPD, and autoimmune hepatitis, was admitted to the ICU with pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure, acute renal failure (ARF), and bacteremia. The patient has been receiving mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and antibiotics.

The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, with a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 182. The patient has bronchial breath sounds and no wheeze on examination.

The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, with a critical aortic stenosis (AS) and a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 30%. The patient has been receiving vasopressors and diuretics to manage her cardiac status.

The patient's renal function is impaired, with an acute kidney injury (AKI) and a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL. The patient has been receiving dialysis and is at risk for further kidney damage.

The patient's blood counts are abnormal, with a white blood cell count of 19.2 x 10^9/L and a platelet count of 81 x 10^9/L. The patient has been receiving antibiotics and is at risk for further bleeding.

The patient's liver function is also impaired, with an elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level. The patient has a history of autoimmune hepatitis and is at risk for further liver damage.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and she is at risk for further respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's critical aortic stenosis and left ventricular dysfunction increase her risk for cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrest or cardiogenic shock.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury and impaired renal function increase her risk for further kidney damage and potential renal failure.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's platelet count is low, and she is at risk for further bleeding complications.
5. Liver damage: The patient's liver function is impaired, and she is at risk for further liver damage.
6. Infection: The patient's bacteremia and pneumonia increase her risk for further infection.
7. Septic shock: The patient's bacteremia and pneumonia increase her risk for septic shock.
8. ARDS: The patient's pneumonia and respiratory failure increase her risk for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

To manage these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored and receive appropriate treatment, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, antibiotics, and dialysis. The patient's family should also be educated on her condition and the potential complications that can arise.

   to discomfort, but oxygenation has been adequate.  Bloody secretions
   suctioned overnight suggest that pulmonary bleed may be intermittently
   continuing.  Sputum culture growing yeast only.
   - hold off on further diuresis given concern for critical AS.
   - repeat bronch this am
   - review CT imaging tonight, consider CT CHEST following bronch
   - obtain TTE, consider TEE to evaluate mitral valve
   - continue vancomcyin/zosyn for HCAP.
   - f/u OSH blood, sputum, and thoracentesis cultures (call in AM, per
   LDH, fluid was transudative, but protein unknown, empyema unlikelygiven
   pH 7.5).
   - wean peep, repeat ABG tonight, consider trial PS.
   - continue prednisone, start tapering as below.
   .
   # aortic stenosis - report of critical AS on TTE at OSH.  unclear what
   her baseline functional status is, she does not have regular angina, or
   syncope
   - repeat TTE
   - consider cardiology consult in AM.
   - hold off on further diuresis, nitrates.
   .
   # ARF - no known renal dysfunction.  found to have mild left
   hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by urology with plan to follow
   clinically.  ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**] diuresis vs aortic
   stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine lytes suggest
   pre-renal etiology.
   - check UA/UCx.
   - check urine lytes.
   - renal ultrasound
   - follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for
   UOP<30cc/hr.
   .
   # bacteremia - source unclear, but likely pulmonary given recent
   pneumonia.
   - continue vancomycin.
   - TTE in AM, and consider TEE.
   .
   # transaminitis - h/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  abdominal usn and ct abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   Lipase not elevated
   - trend LFTs
   - repeat abdominal usn in AM.
   .
   # thrombocytopenia - more likely [**12-31**] underlying liver disease, now with
   reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  ddx also includes DIC,
   HUS/TTP given mild ARF, and HITT, though time course is unclear (he
   received heparin sc tid and lovenox at OSH)
   - check smear to r/o schistocytes (ARF, anemia, thrombocytopenia).
   - check DIC labs.
   - check for HIT.
   .
   # COPD - unclear baseline [**Name (NI) 4232**], but not on home O2.  no clear wheezing
   on exam presently, so feel COPD less likely.
   - taper prednisone 60mg po qdaily to 50mg x3d.
   - continue albuterol, atrovent inhalers.
   - obtain OSH [**Name (NI) 4232**] in AM.
   .
   # h/o aortic valvular thrombus - chronically anticoagulated, though
   held in the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrage (though only
   received 1U PRBC for this at OSH).   no thrombus seen on his recent TTE
   at OSH.
   - hold lovenox/coumadin for now, discuss with cardiology in AM based on
   repeat TTE here.
   - cardiology consult following echo.
   .
   # sacral decub - pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - air mattress.
   - wound care consult.
   .
   # h/o hyponatremia - resolved presently
   - trend na daily.
   .
   # OA - receiving morphine 2mg po prn pain.  per husband, she takes
   percocet at home for pain, but he is unsure where.  a rheumatology note
   indicates she takes percocet for chronic intermittent chest wall pain.
   - continue morphine 0.5mg iv q6hr prn pain.
   .
   # anxiety - per husband, takes anti-anxiety medications at home, and
   receiving lorazepam 0.5-2mg q1hr prn agitation at OSH.
   - continue prn ativan, and monitor for s/sx of withdrawl.

 monitor on tele

hold home statin given transaminitis.

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of aortic stenosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and autoimmune hepatitis, admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with pneumonia, hypoxic respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury (AKI). She has undergone a series of interventions, including bronchoscopy, tube feeding, and antibiotics, and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and vasopressors. Her condition remains unstable, with ongoing respiratory failure, AKI, and suspected bacteremia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely multifactorial, with contributions from pneumonia, pulmonary edema, and pleural effusion. Further diuresis may be necessary to manage her respiratory status.
2. Aortic Stenosis: The patient's critical aortic stenosis requires close monitoring and consideration of valve replacement or valvuloplasty.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's AKI is likely pre-renal in origin, but further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying cause. Monitoring of urine output and electrolytes is crucial.
4. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia is likely pulmonary in origin, and continued antibiotic therapy is necessary. Further evaluation is necessary to determine the source of the bacteremia.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely secondary to her underlying liver disease, bacteremia, and pneumonia. Further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying cause.
6. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis is likely secondary to her autoimmune hepatitis, but further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying cause.
7. Sacral Decubitus Ulcer: The patient's new sacral decubitus ulcer requires wound care and consideration of air mattress support.
8. Hyponatremia: The patient's resolved hyponatremia requires continued monitoring to ensure resolution.
9. Osteoarthritis: The patient's osteoarthritis requires continued pain management with morphine and consideration of physical therapy.
10. Anxiety: The patient's anxiety requires continued management with lorazepam and consideration of anti-anxiety medications.

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and further evaluation to determine the underlying causes of her various complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, COPD, and admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, acute renal failure (ARF), and possible valvuloplasty.

The patient has been treated with antibiotics, diuresis, and drainage of transudative fluid from the right thoracentesis. The patient's blood cultures have grown out pansensitive S. salivarius, and the TTE shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and C-reactive protein (CRP)
* Elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST, and alkaline phosphatase)
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
* Elevated creatinine (1.8 mg/dL) and blood urea nitrogen (BUN)
* Low platelet count (81,000/Î¼L)
* Elevated troponin-T (0.62 ng/mL)

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Intubated, sedated, and on mechanical ventilation
* Elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP)
* Late-peaking systolic murmur (3/6 SEM) on cardiovascular examination
* Bronchial breath sounds on lung examination
* Soft, non-tender, and non-distended abdomen
* Warm, well-perfused, and no edema on extremity examination
* Responds to verbal stimuli on neurological examination

The patient's radiology results show:

* CT chest with gravity-dependent bibasilar consolidative opacities and areas of high-attenuation material in the left base, consistent with a combination of atelectasis, hemorrhage, and infection
* Abd U/S showing gallbladder sludge and wall thickening, possibly chronic liver disease
* B/l pleural effusion and minimal ascites

The patient's potential medical complications are:

* Respiratory failure: multifactorial with contributions from pneumonia, pulmonary edema, and pulmonary hemorrhage
* Endocarditis: S. salivarius, with posterior MV leaflet endocarditis
* Acute kidney injury: possibly due to pre-renal diuresis, aortic stenosis, antibiotics, or obstruction
* Transaminitis: possibly due to autoimmune hepatitis, chronic liver disease, or congestive hepatopathy
* Thrombocytopenia: possibly due to underlying liver disease, bacteremia, or HITT
* COPD exacerbation: possibly due to acute exacerbation or chronic disease progression
* Sacral decubitus ulcer: stage 2, does not probe to bone
* Hyponatremia: resolved, but may recur
* Osteoarthritis: possibly due to chronic intermittent chest wall pain
* Anxiety: possibly due to anti-anxiety medications or withdrawal
* Elevated FSBS: possibly due to steroids or other medications
* H/o SVT: possibly due to electrolyte imbalance or other factors
* HTN: possibly due to ARF or other factors
* Hyperlipidemia: possibly due to transaminitis or other factors

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotics for pneumonia and endocarditis
* Diuresis for ARF
* Drainage of transudative fluid from the right thoracentesis
* Gentle diuresis for goal even
* Weaning of PEEP and trial of pressure support as tolerated
* Tapering of prednisone for COPD
* Continuing albuterol and atrovent inhalers
* Monitoring of LFTs and trend
* F/u of urine cx and ID consult for treatment course and outpt f/u of endocarditis
* Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
* Gentle lasix for goal even
* Avoid decreasing preload or inotropy
* F/u of wound care recs for sacral decubitus ulcer
* Trend Na daily for hyponatremia
* Continue morphine 0.5mg IV q6hr prn pain
* Continue prn ativan and monitor for s/sx of withdrawal
* Cover with HISS for elevated FSBS
* Monitor on tele for SVT
* Holding lisinopril and statin given ARF and transaminitis, respectively.

   structures of the tricuspid valve are thickened/fibrotic. There is
   moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no
   pericardial effusion.
   Compared with the findings of the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2178-10-20**], the left atrial myxoma is no longer present. There is
   now a mass on the posterior mitral leaflet consistent with
   endocarditis.

   the
   patient's low albumin. No cholelithiasis. No specific sign of
   cholecystitis.
   2. Urothelial thickening involving the renal pelves bilaterally, right
   greater than left, and given the bilateral findings, this may represent
   chronic urinary tract infections, particularly fungal. Clinical
   correlation
   is recommended. Also increased echogenicity of the kidneys bilaterally,
   likely reflecting chronic medical renal disease.
   3. Subtle diffuse hepatic nodularity, suggesting the possibility of
   chronic
   liver disease.
   4. Bilateral pleural effusions and minimal ascites.

   75F with h/o aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to OSH with
   pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, ARF, transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty
   for critical AS and found to have mitral valve endocarditis.

   intermittent diuresis and s/p drainage 800cc reportedly transudative

   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation
   # Mitral Valve Endocarditis

   hospital stay at [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius.
   TTE shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis.
   - Cte PCN for Strep salivarius (6 week course started on [**4-30**])
   - ID consult for treatment course and outpt f/u of endocarditis

   # Transaminitis: H/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of aortic stenosis, severe COPD, and pneumonia, who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and mitral valve endocarditis. She has been treated with antibiotics, diuretics, and vasopressors, and has shown some improvement in her respiratory status. However, she remains critically ill with ongoing respiratory failure, and her condition is considered unstable.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she is at risk of developing further respiratory failure, particularly if she experiences another episode of pneumonia or pulmonary edema.
2. Mitral valve endocarditis: The patient has a positive blood culture for Streptococcus salivarius, and her mitral valve endocarditis is likely to be severe and potentially life-threatening.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, and she is at risk of developing further renal failure, which could be life-threatening.
4. Anemia: The patient has bloody secretions from her endotracheal tube and guaiac-positive stools, which could lead to further anemia and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is decreasing, and she is at risk of developing further thrombocytopenia, which could lead to bleeding complications.
6. Hepatic dysfunction: The patient has a history of autoimmune hepatitis, and her liver function tests are abnormal. She is at risk of developing further liver dysfunction, which could be life-threatening.
7. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient has a new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, which could lead to further complications, such as infection and sepsis.
8. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, and she is at risk of developing further hypertension, which could lead to further cardiovascular complications.

Given the patient's critical condition and the potential medical complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of her respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal status, as well as her anemia, thrombocytopenia, and liver function.

   # Hypertension: Likely underlying essential hypertension exacerbated by
   anxiety as resolved when fell asleep.
   - gentle diuresis for fluid goal of even- to slightly positive
   .
   # Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of hospital stay at
   [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius. TTE shows posterior
   MV leaflet endocarditis.
   - Start PCN for Strep viridans
   - ID consult for treatment course and outpt f/u of endocarditis
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   .
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope
   - Will notify Cards on Monday of evaluation for possible valvuloplasty
   - Not candidate for AV replacement given clinical status
   - Gentle lasix for goal even
   - Avoid decreasing preload or negative inotropy
   .
   # ARF: No known renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up. Found
   to have mild left hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by Urology with plan
   to follow clinically. Abd U/S here did not report hydronephrosis but
   did have urothelial thickening suggesting chronic UTI (?fungal) as well
   as chronic renal dysfunction. Ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**]
   diuresis vs aortic stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine
   lytes suggest pre-renal etiology.
   - Follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr
   - Given + yeast in UA and radiologic finding suggestive of possible
   fungal UTI, consider ID consult for appropriate drug in this patient
   with mild transaminitis
   .
   # Transaminitis: H/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  Abdominal U/S and CT abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   Abd u/s here suggests chronic liver disease. Pt currently w/o RUQ pain.
   Ddx includes congestive hepatopathy and autoimmune process.
   - F/u LFTs today and trend
   - Gentle diuresis as above
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Stably decreased. Likely [**12-31**] underlying liver
   disease, now with reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  Ddx
   also includes HITT. No schistocytes on smear to suggest [**Doctor First Name 2674**], and DIC
   unlikely with INR normalizing off coumadin and fibrinogen >100.
   - F/u HIT Ab
   .
   # COPD: Severe emphysema on CT chest with unclear baseline [**Name (NI) 4232**] but not
   on home O2.  No clear wheezing on exam presently, so feel acute
   exacerbation of COPD less likely.
   - Taper prednisone 60mg po qdaily to 50mg x3d.
   - Continue albuterol, atrovent inhalers.
   - Consider obtaining OSH [**Name (NI) 4232**]
   .
   # H/o aortic valvular thrombus: Chronically anticoagulated but held in
   the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrhage (though only received
   1U PRBC for this at OSH). No thrombus seen on his recent TTE at OSH or
   here.
   - Systemic anticoagulation discontinued; can consider d/w Cards
   .
   # Sacral decub: Pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - Air mattress.
   - F/u wound care recs
   .
   # H/o hyponatremia: Resolved presently
   - Trend Na daily.
   .
   # OA: Receiving morphine 2mg po prn pain.  Per husband, she takes
   percocet at home for pain, but he is unsure where.  A rheumatology note
   indicates she takes percocet for chronic intermittent chest wall pain.
   - Continue morphine 0.5mg IV q6hr prn pain.
   .
   # Anxiety: Per husband, takes anti-anxiety medications at home, and
   receiving lorazepam 0.5-2mg q1hr prn agitation at OSH.
   - Continue prn ativan, and monitor for s/sx of withdrawl.
   .
   # Elevated FSBS: No known history of DM, with elevated FSBS on steroids
   - Cover with HISS
   .
   # H/o SVT: Monitor on tele
   .
   # HTN: Holding lisinopril given ARF; avoid nitro or neg inotropes given
   AS
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Holding home statin given transaminitis.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and autoimmune hepatitis. She was admitted to the hospital with pneumonia, hypoxic respiratory failure, and acute renal failure (ARF). She was intubated and transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for difficulty weaning and possible valvuloplasty.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Respiratory failure: Multifactorial, likely contributed by pneumonia, pulmonary edema, and pulmonary hemorrhage. She is being treated with intermittent diuresis and has a pending thoracentesis.
2. Endocarditis: Blood cultures are positive for Streptococcus salivarius, and a transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE) shows posterior mitral valve leaflet endocarditis.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): No known renal dysfunction, but creatinine is trending up. The patient has mild left hydronephrosis, and a urinalysis suggests pre-renal etiology.
4. Transaminitis: Elevated liver function tests (LFTs), and abdominal ultrasound and CT abdomen/pelvis suggest chronic liver disease.
5. Thrombocytopenia: Stably decreased, likely due to underlying liver disease, bacteremia, and pneumonia.
6. COPD: Severe emphysema on CT chest, and the patient is being tapered off prednisone.
7. Sacral decubitus ulcer: Stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not probe to bone.
8. Hyponatremia: Resolved, but the patient's sodium levels will be trended daily.
9. Osteoarthritis: Receiving morphine for pain, and the patient takes percocet at home.
10. Anxiety: Per husband, the patient takes anti-anxiety medications at home, and is receiving lorazepam in the ICU.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening respiratory failure: Continued pulmonary edema, pulmonary hemorrhage, and pneumonia can lead to further respiratory decline.
2. Endocarditis progression: The patient's endocarditis may progress, leading to further complications, such as heart block or valve damage.
3. AKI progression: The patient's AKI may worsen, leading to chronic kidney disease or the need for dialysis.
4. Transaminitis progression: The patient's transaminitis may worsen, leading to liver failure or cirrhosis.
5. Thrombocytopenia progression: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
6. Sacral decubitus ulcer progression: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer may worsen, leading to further tissue damage and infection.
7. Hyponatremia recurrence: The patient's hyponatremia may recur, leading to further electrolyte imbalances.
8. Osteoarthritis progression: The patient's osteoarthritis may worsen, leading to further joint damage and pain.
9. Anxiety and withdrawal symptoms: The patient's anxiety and withdrawal symptoms may worsen, leading to further psychological distress.

The patient's care plan includes:

1. Continued respiratory support: Intermittent diuresis, suctioning of bloody secretions, and weaning of PEEP.
2. Antibiotic therapy: Treatment for endocarditis, pneumonia, and possible fungal UTI.
3. Cardiac care: Monitoring for heart block, and consideration for valvuloplasty.
4. Renal care: Close monitoring of urine output, and possible initiation of dialysis.
5. Liver care: Close monitoring of LFTs, and consideration for liver transplantation.
6. Wound care: Air mattress, and follow-up wound care recommendations.
7. Pain management: Continued use of morphine and lorazepam for pain and anxiety.
8. Psychological support: Monitoring for anxiety and withdrawal symptoms, and consideration for psychotherapy.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with multiple comorbidities. The patient's arterial line was temporarily stopped and restarted due to issues, and a PICC line was ordered but not yet placed. The patient's blood cultures grew Streptococcus salivarius, which is sensitive to penicillin. The patient received antibiotics, including Vancomycin, Zosyn, and Penicillin G, and was started on furosemide, fentanyl, and midazolam infusions. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 51 bpm, blood pressure of 119/49 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's respiratory support includes a ventilator with a tidal volume of 380 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 22 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen of 50%.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient's blood cultures grew Streptococcus salivarius, which may indicate an infection. The patient's antibiotic treatment should be closely monitored to ensure effective treatment and prevent the development of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.
2. Sepsis: The patient's infection and elevated white blood cell count may increase the risk of sepsis. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results is essential to detect any signs of sepsis.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to the patient's underlying condition and the use of mechanical ventilation. Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status and adjusting the ventilator settings as needed are crucial.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, which may indicate hypertension. Close monitoring of the patient's blood pressure and adjusting the medication regimen as needed are essential to prevent complications.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may increase the risk of bleeding complications. Close monitoring of the patient's coagulation status and adjusting the medication regimen as needed are essential to prevent complications.
6. Decubitus Ulcer: The patient's decubitus ulcer may worsen due to the patient's immobility and the use of pressure-reducing devices. Close monitoring of the patient's skin and adjusting the pressure-reducing devices as needed are crucial to prevent further complications.
7. Hypokalemia: The patient's hypokalemia may increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness. Close monitoring of the patient's potassium levels and adjusting the medication regimen as needed are essential to prevent complications.
8. Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS): The patient's respiratory failure and the use of mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of RDS. Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status and adjusting the ventilator settings as needed are crucial to prevent complications.
9. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient's use of mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of VAP. Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status and adjusting the ventilator settings as needed are crucial to prevent complications.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities who requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications. The patient's infection, respiratory failure, and coagulopathy require immediate attention and treatment. The patient's decubitus ulcer, hypokalemia, RDS, and VAP also require close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   75F with h/o aortic stenosis, COPD, admitted to OSH with pneumonia,
   complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, ARF,
   transferred for difficulty weaning and question of valvuloplasty.
   .
   #)Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   PNA, pulmonary edema 2/2 systolic CHF requiring intermittent diuresis
   and s/p drainage 800cc reportedly transudative fluid via R
   thoracentesis at OSH, and pulmonary hemorrhage felt [**12-31**] anticoagulation
   and ?trauma. Bronch yesterday showed lingular abrasion as likely
   source; continuing to suction bloody secretions. Sputum cx growing only
   yeast to date.
   - Patient appears to have been treated with full course of vanc/CTX.
   D/c zosyn and vanc.
   - F/u OSH cx (blood, sputum, thoracentesis)
   - Cycle Hct to ensure stable
   - Holding coumadin (also no longer e/o AV thrombus)
   - Gentle diuresis to run pt even
   - Wean PEEP, trial of pressure support as tolerated. Of note, intubated
   x 13 days, and may need to have trach.
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD
   - F/u final read of CT chest
   .
   # Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of hospital stay at
   [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius. TTE shows posterior
   MV leaflet endocarditis.
   - Start PCN for Strep viridans
   - ID consult for treatment course and outpt f/u of endocarditis
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   .
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope
   - Will notify Cards on Monday of evaluation for possible valvuloplasty
   - Not candidate for AV replacement given clinical status
   - Gentle lasix for goal even
   - Avoid decreasing preload or inotropy
   .
   # ARF: No known renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up. Found
   to have mild left hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by Urology with plan
   to follow clinically. Abd U/S here did not report hydronephrosis but
   did have urothelial thickening suggesting chronic UTI (?fungal) as well
   as chronic renal dysfunction. Ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**]
   diuresis vs aortic stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine
   lytes suggest pre-renal etiology.
   - Follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr
   - F/u urine cx
   .
   # Transaminitis: H/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  Abdominal U/S and CT abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   Abd u/s here suggests chronic liver disease. Pt currently w/o RUQ pain.
   Ddx includes congestive hepatopathy.
   - F/u LFTs today and trend
   - Gentle diuresis as above
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Stably decreased. Likely [**12-31**] underlying liver
   disease, now with reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  Ddx
   also includes HITT. No schistocytes on smear to suggest [**Doctor First Name 2674**], and DIC
   unlikely with INR normalizing off coumadin and fibrinogen >100.
   - F/u HIT Ab
   .
   # COPD: Severe emphysema on CT chest with unclear baseline [**Name (NI) 4232**] but not
   on home O2.  No clear wheezing on exam presently, so feel acute
   exacerbation of COPD less likely.
   - Taper prednisone 60mg po qdaily to 50mg x3d.
   - Continue albuterol, atrovent inhalers.
   - Consider obtaining OSH [**Name (NI) 4232**]
   .
   # H/o aortic valvular thrombus: Chronically anticoagulated but held in
   the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrhage (though only received
   1U PRBC for this at OSH). No thrombus seen on his recent TTE at OSH or
   here.
   - Systemic anticoagulation discontinued; can consider d/w Cards
   .
   # Sacral decub: Pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - Air mattress.
   - F/u wound care recs
   .
   # H/o hyponatremia: Resolved presently
   - Trend Na daily.
   .
   # OA: Receiving morphine 2mg po prn pain.  Per husband, she takes
   percocet at home for pain, but he is unsure where.  A rheumatology note
   indicates she takes percocet for chronic intermittent chest wall pain.
   - Continue morphine 0.5mg IV q6hr prn pain.
   .
   # Anxiety: Per husband, takes anti-anxiety medications at home, and
   receiving lorazepam 0.5-2mg q1hr prn agitation at OSH.
   - Continue prn ativan, and monitor for s/sx of withdrawl.
   .
   # Elevated FSBS: No known history of DM, with elevated FSBS on steroids
   - Cover with HISS
   .
   # H/o SVT: Monitor on tele
   .
   # HTN: Holding lisinopril given ARF; avoid nitro or neg inotropes given
   AS
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of aortic stenosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and autoimmune hepatitis, who was admitted to the hospital with pneumonia and hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation. She has been treated with antibiotics and diuresis, but her condition has remained unstable. The patient's blood cultures have grown Streptococcus salivarius, sensitive to penicillin, and a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) has shown posterior mitral valve leaflet endocarditis. The patient is also experiencing acute kidney injury (ARF), liver dysfunction, and thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient's blood cultures have grown Streptococcus salivarius, which is a virulent organism that can cause endocarditis. The patient's TTE has shown posterior mitral valve leaflet endocarditis, which is a potential complication of endocarditis.
2. ARF: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, and she has mild left hydronephrosis. The patient's urine output is decreasing, and she may require further diuresis to manage her fluid status.
3. Liver Dysfunction: The patient has transaminitis, which is an elevation in liver enzymes. The patient's albumin level is low, which may indicate cirrhosis. The patient's INR is normal, but her bilirubin level is elevated.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is decreasing, which may be related to her underlying liver disease, bacteremia, and pneumonia. The patient may require further evaluation and treatment for thrombocytopenia.
5. Sacral Decubitus Ulcer: The patient has developed a new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Anxiety: The patient is experiencing anxiety, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
7. Elevated FSBS: The patient's fasting serum blood sugar (FSBS) is elevated, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
8. HTN: The patient has hypertension, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
9. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia, which may require further evaluation and treatment.

ICU Care:

The patient is receiving ICU care, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and diuresis. The patient's nutritional needs are being met through a pulmonary diet. The patient's glycemic control is being monitored, and she is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer prophylaxis. The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU.

   - Continue morphine 0.5mg IV q6hr prn pain.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, COPD, and admitted to the hospital with pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, ARF, and transferred for difficulty weaning and question of valvuloplasty.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory failure: Multifactorial with contributions from pneumonia, pulmonary edema, and pulmonary hemorrhage.
* Hypertension: Likely underlying essential hypertension exacerbated by anxiety.
* Endocarditis: Positive blood cultures growing out pansensitive S. salivarius, with posterior MV leaflet endocarditis on TTE.
* Acute kidney injury (ARF): No known renal dysfunction, but Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up, with mild left hydronephrosis at OSH and urothelial thickening on abdominal ultrasound.
* Transaminitis: H/o autoimmune hepatitis, with normal LFTs on admission and on discharge, but elevated INR and low albumin suggesting cirrhosis.
* Thrombocytopenia: Stably decreased, likely due to underlying liver disease, bacteremia, and pneumonia.
* COPD: Severe emphysema on CT chest, but no clear wheezing on exam, suggesting acute exacerbation less likely.
* Sacral decubitus ulcer: New stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not probe to bone.
* H/o hyponatremia: Resolved presently.
* OA: Receiving morphine for pain, with a history of taking percocet at home.
* Anxiety: Per husband, takes anti-anxiety medications at home, and receiving lorazepam for agitation.
* Elevated FSBS: No known history of DM, with elevated FSBS on steroids.
* H/o SVT: Monitor on tele.
* HTN: Holding lisinopril given ARF, and avoiding nitro or negative inotropes given AS.
* Hyperlipidemia: Holding home statin given transaminitis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: Continued hypoxic respiratory failure, ventilator-associated pneumonia, and respiratory arrest.
* Endocarditis: Complicated endocarditis, heart block, and embolic events.
* Acute kidney injury: Progression to chronic kidney disease, need for dialysis, and increased risk of sepsis and mortality.
* Transaminitis: Progression to liver failure, coagulopathy, and increased risk of bleeding.
* Thrombocytopenia: Increased risk of bleeding, and potential for bleeding complications.
* COPD: Acute exacerbation, respiratory failure, and increased risk of mortality.
* Sacral decubitus ulcer: Progression to deeper stages, increased risk of infection, and potential for sepsis.
* OA: Increased pain, decreased mobility, and potential for complications such as respiratory failure and sepsis.
* Anxiety: Withdrawal symptoms, increased anxiety, and potential for complications such as respiratory failure and sepsis.
* Elevated FSBS: Hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, and increased risk of complications such as sepsis and mortality.
* H/o SVT: Recurrence of SVT, and potential for complications such as cardiac arrest and mortality.
* HTN: Hypertensive crisis, cardiac arrest, and increased risk of mortality.
* Hyperlipidemia: Increased risk of cardiovascular events, such as myocardial infarction and stroke.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of her various medical conditions, including respiratory failure, endocarditis, ARF, transaminitis, thrombocytopenia, COPD, sacral decubitus ulcer, OA, anxiety, elevated FSBS, H/o SVT, HTN, and hyperlipidemia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with a complex medical condition. The patient's arterial line was stopped and restarted, and blood cultures grew Streptococcus salivarius sensitive to penicillin. The patient's blood pressure has been elevated, and labetalol was administered to control it. The patient's respiratory status is unstable, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 212, indicating a need for continued respiratory support.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's blood culture growing Streptococcus salivarius suggests the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 212 indicates a need for continued respiratory support, and the patient's respiratory status is unstable, making respiratory failure a potential complication.
3. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure has been elevated, and labetalol was administered to control it. However, hypertension can still be a potential complication, especially if the patient's blood pressure is not adequately controlled.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's PT/PTT/INR values are elevated, suggesting a coagulopathy, which can increase the risk of bleeding.
5. Nutritional deficiency: The patient's nutritional status is compromised, and the patient is receiving enteral nutrition. However, the patient may still be at risk for nutritional deficiency, especially if the patient's nutritional needs are not being met.
6. Decubitus ulcer: The patient has a decubitus ulcer present at admission, which can worsen if the patient is not properly turned and positioned.
7. Hypokalemia: The patient's potassium levels are low, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
8. Respiratory acidosis: The patient's ABG values show a pH of 7.46, which is slightly elevated, suggesting the possibility of respiratory acidosis.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with a complex medical condition. The patient is at risk for various medical complications, including sepsis, respiratory failure, hypertension, coagulopathy, nutritional deficiency, decubitus ulcer, hypokalemia, and respiratory acidosis.

   75F with h/o severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to OSH with
   pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, ARF, transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty
   for critical AS and found to have mitral valve endocarditis.
   .
   #)Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   severe COPD, atalectasis, hemorrhage and edema.  Patient briefly tried
   on PEEP of 6 yesterday but appeared uncomfortable, bradycardia, with
   ABG 7.45/48/63.  Continues to have bloody secretions.  Sputum cultures
   only with yeast to date.
   - Increase sedation for comfort
   - Patient has received full course of vanc/zosyn for HAP
   - To receive trach, hopefully today with IP
   - Plan on DDAVP prior to trach
   - F/u cx
   - Cycle Hct to ensure stable
   - Holding coumadin
   - Gentle diuresis to run pt even
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation
   # Mitral Valve Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of
   hospital stay at [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius.
   TTE shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis.  EKG
s have been unchanged
   to date.
   - Continue PCN for Strep salivarius (6 week course started on [**4-30**])
   - f/u ID consult for treatment course and outpt f/u of endocarditis
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope
   - appreciate cardiology consult today regarding possible interventions,
   she appears to not be a candidate for AV replacement given clinical
   status and endocarditis
   - Avoid decreasing preload or negative inotropy
   # Anemia:  Has bloody secretions from ET tube, oozing from picc site,
   guaiac positive stools.  Hemolysis labs suggest active red cell lysis,
   likely due to mitral valve veg.  Retic count inappropriately low,
   likely due to critical illness.
   - Cycle hcts [**Hospital1 **]
   - Transfuse for hct<21
   .
   # ARF: No known h/o renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up.
   Found to have mild left hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by Urology with
   plan to follow clinically. Abd U/S here did not report hydronephrosis
   but did have urothelial thickening suggesting chronic UTI (?fungal) as
   well as chronic renal dysfunction. Ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**]
   diuresis vs aortic stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine
   lytes suggest pre-renal etiology.
   - Follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr
   - Cx with yeast -> foley changed.
   - f/u urine cx
   # Transaminitis: H/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  Abdominal U/S and CT abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   Abd u/s here suggests chronic liver disease. Pt currently w/o RUQ pain.
   Ddx includes congestive hepatopathy and autoimmune process.
   - Trend LFTs
   - Holding statin
   # Thrombocytopenia: Stably decreased. Likely [**12-31**] underlying liver
   disease, now with reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  Ddx
   also includes HITT. No schistocytes on smear to suggest [**Doctor First Name 2674**], and DIC
   unlikely with INR normalizing off coumadin and fibrinogen >100.
   - F/u HIT Ab
   - Consider hemolysis from endocarditis
   # H/o aortic valvular thrombus: Chronically anticoagulated but held in
   the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrhage (though only received
   1U PRBC for this at OSH). No thrombus seen on TTE at OSH or here.
   - Systemic anticoagulation discontinued; can consider d/w Cards utility
   of continuing anti-coagulation when stable
   # Sacral decub: Pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - Air mattress.
   - F/u wound care recs
   .
   # HTN: Worsens in setting of anxiety. Holding lisinopril given ARF;
   avoid nitro or neg inotropes given AS. Labetolol was effective for her
   HTN. Would use this again if necessary.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TF (on hold for procedure)

   pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, ARF, transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty
